response: That doesn't sound like a good situation for the customer. What happened once you served it to the customer?

context: I was just really nervous. I ended up washing my hands many times just to get the tomato scent out.
response: It is wrong to lick someone's food before serving it to them. While it is almost impossible for them to find out you did this, it is still extremely disrespectful.

context: It's not like I'm making them eat a dirty shoe.
response: This is just the worst nightmare of a customer to have their food licked and served to them. They are paying you for clean food so to do something like this is blatantly disrespectful. You are better off not doing anything like this down the line if you want to keep from getting into trouble.

context: My girlfriend doesn't understand the basic concept of respect, so I think it's time I teach her.
response: I feel like that comes off a bit condescending. Why do you think she is disrespectful?

context: It's because she is so self-centered and doesn't care about others.
response: Sometimes people are unable to perceive how they come off to others. You should try bringing it up in an approachable manner.

context: I agree. I have to draw the line somewhere.
response: Just remember that this is your girlfriend and you're supposed to be equals in your relationship. Talking down to someone will only lead to an imbalance in your relationship.

context: I ghosted the only girl who ever loved me
response: Why would you ghost her? Did you even like her?

context: Yes of course I liked her, she was such a sweet girl, she was almost like a mother.
response: You shouldn't ghost people you care about. The person can feel rejected and may never get closure due to not knowing why they were ghosted. Just be honest and tell them why you want to stop talking to them.

context: I deleted her on every social network and without any explanation she can't get closure.
response: That sounds pretty self-destructive. How would you feel if she did that to you? You should call her and apologize; it's doesn't make sense to throw away a relationship you both want.

context: we should not help poor african children. they are not entitled to food, they should be confident and funny
response: Why would you say that? Are you saying we shouldn't help end world hunger?

context: Yes, it's only about helping people who want to be helped. If they are too dumb to work and earn their own food or if they are mentally incapable to manage their food, they don't deserve any help
response: How do you even come up with that kind of thinking. Africa is in turmoil due to constant war and famine. It is not because they are too dumb or too lazy to work.

context: First of all there is no proof that their situation is because of war and famine. They might be normal family trying to get a good life. Also they can always work hard to earn their food and I don't see why we should help them
response: You need to change your opinions about African people. It's mean to think that they don't deserve to eat or our help.

context: I was hoping to ask my ride if they would mind leaving a little earlier.
response: I am thinking that maybe she is not ready to leave.

context: That's why I want to ask her very politely and in a nice tone also.
response: That sounds like the best way to approach it. Like my grandmother used to say, "You catch more flies with honey than with vinegar!" It's betting than demanding.

context: She has to leave earlier. I want to leave so I can catch the train.
response: Well that sounds like it works also. Either way, asking in a respectful way seems like it is the best approach to getting what you may want!

context: "Have you ever been threatened with rape by a woman?" Yes. Many times, but ONLY by feminist women.
response: I don't quite follow what you're saying here. Are you implying that feminists are supposed to be rapists?

context: I won't say that all of them are rapists, but certainly a lot of them are.
response: I think that feminists are just trying to work to get society to view women as equals to men. Historically, women have been treated in a disrespectful way and when people say things like feminists are rapists, it only encourages that disrespect. You should try to be more sympathetic to other people.

context: I am not interested in getting involved in other people's business. I don't care about how you feel.
response: If that's the case, wouldn't it be best to just ignore the feminist movement if you don't have anything kind to say about them? I feel like this is what they are fighting for, so why not try to educate yourself a bit and learn what women have to go through every day?

context: I'm thinking of keeping a secret stash of abandoned children in the abandoned mine.
response: I am very concerned with this. Are you really serious you have abandoned kids hidden somewhere in an abandoned mine?

context: Yes, I'm absolutely serious. It's not a joke.
response: Keeping a stash of abandoned kids anywhere is not only highly immoral, but also highly illegal. If you want to avoid prison time and a felony record, you should forget about kidnapping kids. You should not make jokes like that either, and probably should talk to a therapist about your ideas.

context: Okay, but I wonder if there is actually a way to do it without getting into trouble. Like El Chapo.
response: No illegal activity will be free from repercussions and penalty, and I hope that you realize that. Instead of focusing what you can do illegally, I suggest you focus on what you can do to help your neighbors and people around you to have better lives, as we all need a little bit of help we can get, rather than doing something illegal. Don't you agree?

context: How to I tell if my father is abusive or not?
response: What makes you believe he's abusive?

context: I found bruises on my mom's body and I think he did it.
response: Mysterious bruises showing up on someone can be a red flag of abuse in a relationship. If you believe your father is being abusive then you should try talking to your mother about. If she refuses to talk about it you may need to get other family involved.

context: It's worse than I thought. It was very depressing. I am devastated and feel betrayed by my father.
response: You should talk with you mother and see how long this has been going on for. She may need to get some help if this has been an ongoing thing. There are many resources out there for her to get help.

context: What if I'm thinking of giving a fiery speech about how Jews are an invasive species?
response: I can't believe you'd ever say that. That's an absurd conspiracy theory.

context: I'm sure you won't believe me, you alien sons of bitches
response: You shouldn't believe conspiracy theories and act on them. That's what Hitler did and how he ended up being one of the worst people in history. Think things through logically and realize that conspiracy theories can be dangerous.

context: You are shadow-brained Jew
response: Judging and making inflammatory comments about a specific group of people is not okay. You should show others the same respect that you would want to see.

context: Can I resent my mom?
response: Are you for real? Why do you resent your mom?

context: My mom is always like you can't be like that. You can't dress like that. You can't talk like that
response: It's frustrating when a parent is constantly telling you what you can't do rather than uplifting and supporting you and who you are. You should have a conversation with your mom about her actions and how it's making you feel and hopefully she'll be understanding and make an effort to change.

context: It's not like I'm strung out on drugs and I'm going to rehab. She needs to chill out.
response: Yeah totally. If I were you, I would feel the same way, so like I said, you need to figure out how to approach her when the time is right and have a discussion about your maturity and how you don't want to feel like you are constantly being babysat, especially when you are almost an adult.

context: I'm planning to drive home after drinking 3 bottle of wine at the winery.
response: I hope you aren't serious. You should not be drinking and driving.

context: I know it is not a good idea after I had my memory tested, but the view of my life is quite complex and I would like to relax with wine.
response: Its really bad to drive after drinking this much. Driving drunk can not only kill you, but also other people on the road. Your attention is impaired after drinking and you need to do your best to be careful.

context: No worries its just a short drive.
response: No amount of distance is safe to drink drunk. You might confuse the gas for the break pedal. Please have someone else drive you home or call a taxi.

context: I backed the van filled with people into the swamp.
response: Why did you back the van with people into the swamp?

context: Because I needed an excuse to miss my kid's birthday party.
response: There is never an excuse to put people in danger like that. You could have very easily killed all of the people in the van if the van had gone under into the swamp.

context: Oh, well I'm just not a people person.
response: I hope everyone was ok afterwards, this was extremely reckless and illegal. If you need to avoid a social situation, then muster up the courage to say you don't want to go or find a better excuse, never put others in danger to cause an accident as a way out.

context: I want to buy a snake against my boyfriends wishes
response: Why do you want a snake so bad?

context: Because I think that snakes are nice and pretty.
response: Its fine to disagree with what your partner wants sometimes, however if you live together it is not a great idea to still get a snake. Sharing a living space requires your partner and you to compromise. Blatantly going against their wishes is not very moral.

context: Nah, I want to prove that I'm the boss and him being with me is not even half as important.
response: You are allowed to have a disagreement with your partner but you should still value their input. If the snake is an issue, you should try to find a way to compromise.

context: I'm going to ask my husband to return my anniversary gift
response: Why? Didn't you like his anniversary gift to you?

context: No, I want to let him know the gift isn't suitable for me
response: We often give gifts to re-confirm or establish our connection with others, which means that they're a reflection of both the giver and the receiver, as well as their unique relationship. Accept the gift with grace and don't return it.

context: I'm not accepting the gift, it's better for me to wait for my husband to return the present.
response: If you really hate the gift you can just tell him sincerely and just try to tell him that you appreciate the thought and ask him nicely if he can still return it. The key is to appreciate his effort and not be angry about it as he meant well with the gift even if you did not like it.

context: The kid I got stuck babysitting ended up with a nasty runny nose, so I poured the child a cup of gin for his cold
response: You gave a child some gin for it's cold? Isn't there something else kid friendly you could have done? Where are the child's parents?

context: The child's father is in the hospital. He only needs small amounts of gin in his drink, just to be able to sleep.
response: You needed a quick fix for a sick child to sleep in your care, but this isn't suitable for a child and could make them sick. Take some over the counter medicine made for kids and give the child that.

context: I just needed something to work fast, and I didn't have time to run through the store and get the other medicine.
response: I get the urgency you must have felt from seeing the kid sick and miserable like that, but it's important that you don't give kids alcohol. If you end up in this situation again check into getting some children's medicine delivered.

context: I was really racist when I was younger
response: Why were you racist?

context: I even supported the thought of castration for Muslims.
response: It's immoral to be racist. You should tolerate all races.

context: I'm just saying that it's okay to be racist towards Muslims.
response: Well, you can't single out one group of people and claim you're not racist. It wrong to discriminate against anyone.

context: I stayed home from school because I just wasn't in the mood today.
response: So you got away with it. Did your parents find out?

context: I think my teacher was sort of shocked I did it again. She told me that I need to work harder in my life.
response: You should not stay home from class just because you don't feel like going. It makes more sense to try and go so you don't miss anything. Your teacher is right to be upset about this.

context: And this is why I don't like school.
response: It's not always fun, but your education is important and you should take it seriously. If you go to college, you'll have more control over the classes you take, and you may enjoy being there more than you do now.

context: Last week there was a moose in the road so I stopped my car, got out, and took a knife to that moose.
response: Did that really happen? Why would you kill the moose?

context: Oh yeah, it happened. I don't care about moose.
response: It doesn't matter if you hate moose, you need to respect wildlife and not kill them. They don't know what's going on, or that they're disrupting traffic. You shouldn't waste your time getting out of your car, just leave the moose alone and drive along your way.

context: You know what's wasting my time, explaining this to you.
response: You don't have to explain it. I just think it's wrong to kill wildlife for no reason. That moose wasn't bothering you or anyone else, so stopping your car and taking a knife to it was an awful thing to do.

context: This depressed friend is on my last nerve.
response: Why would you snap at someone who's in a depression?

context: I always feel like he wants to take advantage of me by acting like a helpless dog when he's depressed.
response: When people like your friend are depressed they often don't know how to reach out correctly, so you snapping at him in an impatient manner doesn't help. Find some sympathy for him and restrain your annoyance so that you can help him.

context: He's being bitching about same shit. It's like he's trying to guilt trip me to feel bad.
response: I understand your annoyance, but you should not snap at them.

context: I shot a child in the eye at the shooting range.
response: What happened? Did you intent to shoot the child?

context: No, and I feel so guilty about it. I should have asked for help with the gun.
response: While it is good that you feel remorse, it is very serious to shoot another person, especially a child. You need to practice safety precautions with guns; they are deadly weapons and shouldn't be treated lightly.

context: But... It's not that bad.
response: It's good to feel remorse about shooting the child. It's important to be careful with guns no matter where you are.

context: I'm not going to claim my farts
response: What do you mean ?

context: I won't take any responsibility for the fart noise.
response: It's sort of rude to fart in front of others, if you can help it. If you do it, it should not be ignored by you. There's is nothing wrong in accepting that you farted.

context: Well shucks. I'm going to fart away and deny it.
response: Farting around others is disgusting. You should not do this as it can gross people out and make them think you are unhygienic.

context: I don't want my roommate's bf in our dorm as I shower
response: Are you scared of what he might do?

context: He would peek when I shower and I hate the idea of it.
response: You roommates boyfriend should respect your privacy. You should talk to her and set up boundaries so you feel safe.

context: It would be stupid if I talk to her. I want to kick him out and make him homeless.
response: You shouldn't want to kick him out on some baseless accusation. Close the bathroom door and lock it.

context: I was very proud of the SAT test scores I got for Henry
response: So you did the test for him? Why are you proud of that?

context: Henry said he got a high score, so I'm very proud of his hard work.
response: What you are doing is illegal and academically dishonest. If you're found out, you may be banned from ever taking such tests again and your scores invalidated. This person won't be able to go to many colleges as a result, sitting in like this really screwed up your futures.

context: What does that matter? People who do well in college are boring. It's all about the partying and networking.
response: While networking and relaxation are in important, learning your studies is more important. Future employers want to know if you know how to do your job well and if you're knowledgeable. Having someone cheat for you will not let you learn the subjects you need to learn in order to be successful.

context: 'm going to anonymously let my  friend's gf know he cheated on her
response: Do you know for a fact he cheated or do you want to find out?

context: I have evidence that proved he cheated on her
response: It isn't good to meddle.  However, cheating is bad too.

context: It's her fault that she didn't pay attention!  But I feel bad for her.
response: I hope both your friend and his soon to be ex girlfriend learn from this!  Cheating is wrong and is never acceptable.  Good for you, calling it out!
